bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 27, 1939

div1.p: Hench discusses his interest in the story of the conquest of yellow fever and asks for Kean's involvement.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 27, 1939
div1.opener:
October 27, 1939
Gen. Jefferson R. Kean
U. S. Army, Retired
2804 N. Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I have become interested in the fascinating story of the conquest
of yellow fever by Dr. Walter Reed and his colleagues. A couple of years ago
I became acquainted with Mr. John Kissinger who was one of the first to receive
the experimental yellow fever. I had the privilege of visiting him in his home
and he has visited here at the Mayo Clinic and has given a talk, at my request,
before the members of our staff. I have had some interesting correspondence
also with Mr. John Moran. It was my suggestion that both of these men publish
brief personal stories of their experiences which I should be glad to help
place in our best medical historical magazines. In discussing the story with
each of them I found I came across certain controversial points which apparently
have never been decided and which cannot be satisfactority decided by either
Mr. Moran or Mr. Kissinger alone.

Mr. Moran has taken the liberty of suggesting that you might be
willing to help in this work, and I am delighted at the suggestion. Mr. Moran
has indicated that perhaps you might be willing to dictate answers to a list
of questions that I might send to you, but I believe this would not be satis-
factory to either one of us and perhaps the matter could be done more satis-
factorily and less fatigueingly to you if I could visit you sometime in the
not too distant future in Washington. I hope to visit Mr. Moran in Havana in
March and perhaps after that I could visit you in Washington. If you should
prefer, I should be glad to submit to you a list of questions concerning the
controversial points, which list you could answer at your leisure and convenience.
I have assured Mr. Moran that you are such an authority on the subject and that
perhaps it might be best for all concerned if you yourself would write up the
story with such help as I could give you. On the other hand, if you do not care
to do so I should be glad to accept your collaboration as the editor of the two
stories which I am helping Mr. Moran and Mr. Kissinger to prepare. It would be
indeed a great privilege to have you as coeditor in this venture, and you could
make such comments and notes as you think best.

I hasten to tell you that my purpose is purely unselfish and the venture
is taken on purely from my interest in medical history. Medical historical
magazines offer no fee for such articles and the best I could do is to get reprints
for their own pleasure. However, it is possible that once the matter is down in
black and white for the medical magazine that it could be written in a more
popular style for some such journal as the “Saturday Evening Post”. Whatever fees
Gen. Jefferson Kean
-2-
October 27, 1939
we might be able to get for the article I can assure you will be turned over
entirely to Mr. Moran and Mr. Kissinger as it is their story written in
their way that the public is interested in and not my comments.
I shall be grateful to hear from you at your convenience.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds:if
